BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Slight increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the mostly small wind slabs that are being formed by the moderate to strong northwesterly wind can still be released in some cases in particular on steep northeast, south and southwest facing slopes above approximately 2300 m.
In particular intermediate and high altitudes: In particular on wind-loaded slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain more small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular at intermediate and high altitudes and along the border with Switzerland.
Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the wind slabs will increase in size from late morning. The snowpack will become in some cases unstable. Sunny slopes: As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust will form on the surface during the next few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: These conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In some localities 70 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m.
In all aspects numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches were observed. As a consequence of the strong southerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed.
On steep sunny slopes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
Several large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible in the regions with a lot of snow.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of dry and moist avalanches being released will increase a little in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. On steep sunny slopes and in steep rocky terrain more avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones.
New snow and wind slabs can in some cases be released by a single winter sport participant, but they will be small in most cases. In the regions exposed to a lot of wind this applies especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, places that are protected from the wind:
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, along the border with France.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing moistening of the snowpack in some places on sunny slopes. Sunny slopes: As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust will form on the surface during the next few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
In all aspects avalanches occurred naturally. As a consequence of the southerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed.
On steep sunny slopes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on west to north to southeast facing aspects. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation such avalanche prone locations are more widespread. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized.

As a consequence of solar radiation individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1500 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size moderately on Tuesday.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs require caution. The weather conditions will bring about a stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of solar radiation individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow of the last three days represents the main danger. The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase during the day. Below approximately 2200 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. The new snow of the weekend can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects at high altitude. The new snow of the last few days is very loosely bonded in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area in some localities up to 60 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 1900 m. The new snow of the last few days is very loosely bonded in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2100 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Sunday the wind has been moderate to strong in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland. Here soft wind slabs formed.
The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2000 m. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

On extremely steep slopes and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain individual natural dry avalanches are possible, but they can reach medium size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Is lying on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Afternoon: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the activity of small and medium moist and wet avalanches will increase, in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Avalanches can in isolated cases reach medium size.

On steep grassy slopes individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, especially in the regions with a lot of snow in the north. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

On extreme sunny slopes individual loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form on Tuesday adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects. The older wind slabs of last week have bonded well with the old snowpack. No distinct weak layers exist in the bottom section of the snowpack. The solar radiation will give rise to slight moistening of the snowpack on sunny slopes.

Intermediate altitudes: The snowpack will be moist. At low altitude only a little snow is now lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will bring about a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Sunday the wind has been strong in some localities in some regions. Particularly in the valley heads.
The soft wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on northeast to southeast to southwest facing aspects above the tree line. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

On steep slopes and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain more natural dry avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m. In many places new snow is being deposited on bare ground (--), in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Is lying on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Afternoon: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the activity of small and medium moist and wet avalanches will increase, in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Individual natural loose snow slides are possible, even medium-sized ones. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects and at elevated altitudes. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of solar radiation individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places by people in particular on very steep shady slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects and at elevated altitudes. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of solar radiation individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More recent wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. In isolated cases the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects and at elevated altitudes. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A lot of rain has fallen. Above approximately 1800 m snow has fallen in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular on sunny slopes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.
